awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Tracking carbon allocation to unravel how a mutualism and its breakdown affect the carbon cycle
awd_abstract_narration:
Trees are key players in the carbon cycle because they recycle atmospheric carbon dioxide into forms of carbon that living things can use. To be successful, most trees require animals or microbes to provide them with services, e.g., with defense against enemies or to supply them with nutrients. Trees reward these service providers, known as mutualists, with carbon. Tree mutualists thus probably have large impacts on the carbon cycle, but these impacts have rarely been quantified. This research seeks to determine how much carbon from trees is invested in mutualists, where that carbon comes from, and whether that carbon investment changes when mutualisms are disrupted by human-driven changes in the animal fauna. The project will leverage a mutualism between trees and defensive ants in Kenya that is uniquely well-suited to field experiments and landscape modeling, in order to determine how mutualists contribute to the carbon cycle. This research will be communicated to K-12 students throughout the country using a web-based education platform designed to teach biology through active learning.

Symbiotic ant colonies protect Acacia drepanolobium trees against herbivores in Kenyan savannas in exchange for housing and carbohydrates, but this mutualism is disrupted by the disappearance of megaherbivores and by an invasive ant species. Ant mutualists reduce tree growth and reproduction in the absence of herbivory, but this apparent carbon cost of ants has never been investigated relative to other critical tree carbon sinks, including allocation to roots and microbial mutualists. The proposed work will investigate carbon pools and dynamics in A. drepanolobium in the context of variation in the tree's biotic interactions to discover how mutualists affect tree carbon allocation. Using field experiments to manipulate ant mutualists, megaherbivores, and invasive ants, this research will evaluate how much trees invest in their mutualists relative to tree carbon supply, and how new carbon assimilates are partitioned between mutualists and tree sinks. Carbon allocation will be assessed by measuring biomass, nonstructural carbohydrates, secondary metabolites, mutualist rewards, and by pulse labeling of new assimilates. Because A. drepanolobium is a monodominant tree across large areas of East Africa, these measurements will be important to predicting changes in ecosystem-level carbon storage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how trees respond to stress in their environments is important to understanding the future health of terrestrial ecosystems. Increasingly, we must also understand how trees respond to multiple stressors in combination, and whether we can accurately predict these responses from studies of individual stressors. For example, invasive species are estimated to cost North America over $26 billion dollars per year by negatively affecting crop and native species. Invasive species have negative impacts on trees that live in complex ecological systems, where trees also experience numerous other stressors, such as herbivory and drought. Most trees engage in positive interactions, known as mutualisms, which enable them to persist in more stressful conditions than they would otherwise be able to withstand. Yet we still understand little about the connections between mutualism and tree responses to stress, as well as whether these connections change as stressors multiply.

In this research, we aimed to use carbon as a common currency to quantify both tree responses to multiple stressors and tree engagement with mutualists. Trees fix carbon from the atmosphere into sugars, and they allocate these sugars to storage, growth, and mutualist partner species. How trees allocate their sugars should thus shed light on their fitness strategy, i.e., on how they achieve the highest survival and reproduction during their lifetime, and on its limitations.

We studied a foundational tree in East African savannas, which commonly makes up >90% of tree cover in certain soils. The savannas are semi-arid, and trees are frequently water-limited during the dry seasons. The tree, Acacia (Vachellia) drepanolobium, is a favorite food of various megaherbivores in the system, including elephants, giraffes, and black rhinoceros, and it employs aggressive ants to defend it against this herbivory. The ants live inside the tree's stems and eat its sugars, and in return the ants attack herbivorous animals by biting them in large numbers, which reduces herbivory on the tree. In addition to drought and herbivory, these trees have recently been suffering from the effects of an invasive ant species, the big-headed ant, Pheidole megacephala. The invasive ants live in the soil but forage in the trees and can eliminate the defensive ant species, leaving the trees vulnerable to herbivory.

We made several new discoveries as a result of our research. First, in addition to increasing herbivory on the trees, the invasive ants are having negative impacts on trees by disrupting their roots. Although invasive ants are found on nearly every continent and usually nest in the soil, we know surprisingly little about their effects on vegetation. Our results show that the trees were unable to grow or maintain their roots in the soils where the big-headed ants are nesting, which appears to reduce tree carbon fixation and negatively impact tree carbon budgets and lifetime reproduction. We also found that the negative impacts of the invasive ants on tree growth were exacerbated during droughts, suggesting that invasive ants and drought in combination have more negative effects on tree populations than either stressor would have in isolation. We additionally discovered that herbivory strongly reduces tree carbon budgets in this system, which creates trade-offs: trees can allocate to the growth of stems or to the growth of roots, but not both, in the presence of herbivory. Because stem growth is necessary to escape the heaviest herbivory and the risk of fire, whereas root growth is necessary to uptake sufficient water, these trade-offs also likely have negative impacts on tree populations. Finally, trees allocate a measurable proportion of their total sugars to their defensive ant mutualists, although the cost of the ants in sugars depends on which of several ant species the tree employs. We should be able to use these measurements to understand the role that mutualisms play in tree population persistence in future work.

In addition to these scientific discoveries, we also made several methodological advances. We showed that it is possible to track tree carbon allocation in real time in a field system at the equator, which will enable future studies of the importance of species interactions to tree responses to stress. We also showed that it is possible to image fine roots in this field system, which will produce some of our first understanding of these dynamics in savanna systems, which are important to global carbon cycling. Finally, we successfully applied machine learning to the analysis of our root images, which enables faster processing of these data and will encourage further studies.

This project provided mentorship and facilitated the career development for five students and a postdoctoral reseacher, and we provided training and employment for four Kenyan field technicians. The project also produced a savanna virtual reality experience on the web aimed at American K-12 students, which explains the purpose of the research and introduces the students to some of the charismatic savanna animals.
